description:
The summer being not the best time to launch OTS, I propose to meet in the first half of September to give OTS a strong start.

During this meet up, apart from chatting and drinking, we'll have to organise and prepare the first workshop(s):

- Agree on a topic
- Gather coaches
- Possibly create learning material
- Find a venue / Set up a date
- Spread the word / Find students
name: Let's get to know each other and launch our first workshop.

description:
A series of 9 Drupal workshops. Learn how to build a complete website with Drupal.
We start each day with a good hacker breakfast and go on with the Drupal workshop afterwards.
The Drupal Hacker Dawns are each saturday, from 10am until 15pm.
The workshops are free to attend, but we ask 4 euro to cover the breakfast costs.
The first workshop will be on 5 october and continue until 30 november.

## Who is this for?

Everyone with little or no Drupal experience.
Some basic knowledge of HTML and CSS is advised.

## What will I learn?

- Drupal terminology like nodes, fields, blocks & views
- Build a complete website from scratch
- Update versions of Drupal core and contributed modules
- Use Drush, command line shell and scripting interface for Drupal
- More advanced usage, have your configuration in code, for example
- That you can do this!

## What do I need?

- Bring your laptop with you. If you don't have one, let me know, we have some public laptops at the space available. Any operating system is fine.
- Some ideas on what you want to build. What features would you like on your website?
- Courage to get out of bed on a saturday morning ;)

https://hackerspace.be/Hacker_Dawn:_Drupal
name: Learn how to build a website with Drupal

description:
The workshop is about creating a smartphone app using Android. In the manner of Open Tech School, you will learn at your own pace to start developing apps with Android. The course material is available on developer.android.com/training/index.html. However, we will use Android Studio instead of Eclipse.

Prerequisite is some programming knowledge, ideally in Java.

Please bring your own computer/laptop or leave a note below if you can't bring one.
name: Creating Smartphone Apps (with Android)

description:
This is the first part of a 4 hours workshop aimed at helping beginners to programming or to Python getting their hands on the language. The second part will take place on the following Monday. Part 2: http://www.meetup.com/OpenTechSchool-Brussels/events/144891682/


Python is this thing called a programming language. It takes text that you’ve written (usually referred to as code), turns it into instructions for your computer, and runs those instructions. We’ll be learning how to write code to do cool and useful stuff. No longer will you be bound to use others’ programs to do things with your computer!

This first workshop will offer complete beginners the opportunity to learn Python using the Introduction to Programming with Python [1] class from OpenTechSchool, and people with some some programming knowledge the opportunity to learn Python by building web applications through the easy Websites with Python Flask [2] class.


It would be great if some coaches could demo some nice uses of Python at the end of the workshop, so please comment if you can show some of the awesomeness you do with it.


[1] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-beginners/en/index.html
[2] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-flask/
name: Learn Programming with Python (part 1/2)

description:
In this workshop, you will learn the basics of the Java programming language.

Our first program will be a text-based game. But not any game: your game! You will learn all that is needed for the structure, but the story, all the adventures and twists will be yours to invent, all free. No rules here!


Java is a general-purpose, object-oriented computer programming language. It is intended to let developers "write once, run anywhere". Any people with Java will be able to use directly what you're creating, no matter which system they are on. Java is heavily used in the industry by major companies like Google and used to create software like Minecraft.

Through this workshop, you will learn the basics of programing as a whole, and how it specially works in Java: how to use variables, to display text, to test conditions, to create functions and to loop over them.

Please bring your own computer/laptop or leave a note below if you can't bring one.

Materials: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1phFeykfrPgTI3u-rKD8C94tKlRct_CbzX1a5vCOlXYI/edit?usp=sharing
name: [Beginner] Program a text-based game using Java

description:
Learners meetup are regular meetups inside the OTS community, in parallel with workshops. These meetings are for people interested in continuing learning and sharing with people of same interest. You can come, present, attend presentations and ask for help about your projects.

These meetups are open to complete beginners.


If you attend, please add a comment to the even and tell us what help you can provide, or the topics you would want to discuss. And please vote for the time & date on the associated doodle: http://doodle.com/4c6wwaqdde7ms85r


For more background on learners meetup: http://www.opentechschool.org/handbooks/learners-meetups.html
name: Learners meetup #1

description:
This is the second part of a 4 hours workshop aimed at helping beginners to programming or to Python getting their hands on the language. The first part will take place on the previous Monday.

http://www.meetup.com/OpenTechSchool-Brussels/events/140007312/
name: Learn Programming with Python (part 2/2)

description:
So, you just started with Python...

You want to continue learning and building your skills?
You have a wonderful program idea, or want to join a project?
You want to present your project and have feedbacks?

Then come to this python flavored learners meetup and brainstorm with us as to what project we can get going. Personal projects or team projects are welcomed. Everybody is welcome to join this learners meetup, but the emphasis will be given to helping and launching projects in Python.
name: Learners meetup #2: Special Python

description:
The workshop is about creating a smartphone app using Android. In the manner of Open Tech School, you will learn at your own pace to start developing apps with Android. The course material is available on developer.android.com/training/index.html. However, we will use Android Studio instead of Eclipse.

Prerequisite is some programming knowledge, ideally in Java.

Please bring your own computer/laptop or leave a note below if you can't bring one.
name: [Beginner] Creating Smartphone Apps on Android #CodeEU

description:
This workshop is about getting to know basic JavaScript, a language that is used to create web applications, i.e. programs that can be run from an internet browser.

During the workshop, you will work with the Chrome browser (please install beforehand). The material is available online at http://opentechschool.github.io/js-beginners-4h-workshop-1/

You don't need to have programming knowledge! This workshop is for complete beginners. Everyone is welcome to come and learn together whatever your level in programming is.

We have a few chromebooks available, please leave a message in the comments if you need a computer to work with.
name: [Starter] Programming a Web App using JavaScript #CodeEU

description:
RFID is a technology for short range interaction between two devices: a scanner and a chip, usually embedded in physical objects. In our case, these will be cards, which you’ll use to create a battle card game.

Radio-frequency identification (RFID) is found in many applications: the MOBIB cards, access badges, anti-theft systems... We will provide USB scanners for this workshop, as well as white cards containing the RFID chips.
Your first RFID application will be a battle-style card game programmed in Python and based on an old classic: rock-paper-scissors. First, setup up your deck: full rocks? scissors and paper? Then, challenge your opponent. During your game, you’ll gain knowledge of your opponent’s white cards deck. Use that to your advantage!
Through this workshop, you will learn the basics of RFID technology and the vCard data structure used as virtual business card. After this workshop, up to you to create your own application!

Requirement:
1)Basic knowledge of Python or other programming language. Not sure of your level? Check the materials of our first Python workshop.
2)Bring your laptop (warn us if you come without one). Extra: grab your NFC-enabled phone if you have one

Lead Coach: Djo
Coaches: Bernard, Roman

Materials: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1E9KInD_SOvnVeVjyTl-jxm2cOtt2CD3FeZzmrvJEyxw/edit

venue.name: ULB Campus Solbosch Batiment K, third floor, room K.3.401

name: [Beginner] Discover RFID:  create a battle card game

description:
A full day about about this new web programming language that is similar to javascript but made for web applications.

Registration required at bit.ly/dartBE14

Saturday:

Techtalks, Workshops, Codelabs

Sunday:

OpenHackDay

See also bit.ly/dartBE14 for details
name: Learn Modern Web programming with Dart

description:
This is the first workshop of a series of monthly Python workshops for beginners, every third Tuesday of the month.

Python is this thing called a programming language. It takes text that you’ve written (usually referred to as code), turns it into instructions for your computer, and runs those instructions. We’ll be learning how to write code to do cool and useful stuff. No longer will you be bound to use others’ programs to do things with your computer!

This workshop will offer complete beginners the opportunity to learn Python using the Introduction to Programming with Python [1] class from OpenTechSchool, and people with some some programming knowledge the opportunity to learn Python by building web applications through the easy Websites with Python Flask [2] class. [1] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-beginners/en/index.html
[2] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-flask/

venue.name: Room K.3.401, Building K, Third floor, ULB Campus Solbosch

name: Learn Programming with Python (March)

description:
Processing is a set of tools, including a programming language, designed to facilitate the use of software within the visual arts, and to promote visual representations within technology. Processing is focused on making digital creation simple and fun, with an emphasis on visuals and interactions. This makes it particularly fitted for makers, designers and visual artists.

Whether you plan to create an artistic installation, an original Android App or simply to learn how to code, Processing is one of the best resources available. It is used by tens of thousands of students, artists/designers, researchers, and hobbyists worldwide.

After discovering the Processing environment, we will discover what generative art is and get our hands dirty. While we will have material to guide you as for every OTS workshop, we will try our best to let you free to explore personal direction within this frame. This workshop is not only about learning technical stuff, but also about expressing your creativity through technology and sharing your realizations.

During this workshop, you will learn the basics of programming, how to use Processing and its development environment (IDE) to create visual effects that people can interact with. By the end of the workshop, we hope to make you autonomous with Processing so you can start your own projects.

This workshop will be located at iMal,  centre for digital cultures. Thanks a lot to the iMal team for making this workshop possible!


Requirement:

1) Bring your laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux, no problem)

2) Optional: Download and set up Processing on your machine.

Note: If you don’t have a laptop, warn us in advance so we can bring one for you.

Lead coach: Roman

Coach: Hugo 

Materials: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vUk5zjtTrIiEcwbJ_e-PCi9zVOy7kTtqRNGFWZ7koSk
name: [Beginner] Create generative art with Processing

name: [Beginner] Create generative art with Processing

description:
Music is sound; it is a signal. As such, computers are good at generating, recording and manipulating it. This is partly why they are wildly used in music creation nowadays, would that be as a studio (recording, mastering…), to perform and launch samples, or straight as a music instrument. If many softwares exist to abstract these tasks, through this workshop we want you to get a low-level and deep understanding of the element at play: sound, signal, waves, frequencies, timbre...

Through this workshop, you’ll be coding in C++ with SFML for interaction, and RTaudio for the sound part. You’ll use it to record and play samples, then to create instruments and effects. For those that are interested, you will have the possibility to create a VST plugin, a module that you can plug in music application such as Ableton Live, GarageBand & others.

During the workshop, you’ll be heavily encouraged to actually perform and play/test the multiple instruments you’ll be creating. Depending on the feedback from the students, we will organize a little concert to showcase what has been done during the workshop.


Requirement

1) Basic knowledge of C++ (variable, function, structure/class, pointers...). Not sure of your level? Check the materials of our first Java or Python workshop to have an idea of what would be useful.

2) Bring your laptop (warn us if you come without one).

3) Bring your headphones!!!

4) Optional: install SFML RTaudio and create/compile an empty project. This will be covered in the first part of the material, available *soon*.


Lead Coach: Pierre

Coaches: Roman

Materials: http://opentechschool-brussels.github.io/blast-it/
name: Blast it: Create music with your sound card.

description:
Android Wear is a framework for Smartphones that are connected to Android phones. The framework allows to quickly extends existing Android apps from phones to smartwatches.

During this workshop you will learn how to using Nofifications in Android and how this will work with Android Wear.

Android Wear is a lot about design, fashion and user experience. Therefore this event is also for not-developers. We will also have probably one Smartwatches and at least one Google Glass devices for you to work with.

Prerequisites

1. Familiarity with Java programming language

2. Ideally, an Android phone or tablet for testing. The Android Wear developer preview emulator is designed to work with a real Android companion device.

Setup for Designers 1. Read the Android Wear design principles

2. Join the +Android Wear Developers community:  g.co/androidweardev


Setup your laptop for development

1. Sign up for the Developer Preview (can take up to 24 hrs for approval): http://developer.android.com/wear/preview/signup.html

You should get a confirmation email that includes

a) link to the Android Wear Developer Preview support library

b) link to opt-in to the Android Wear Preview app beta distribution in the Google Play store

2. If you haven’t already, download and install Android Studio:

a) Download Android Studio from: http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html

b) Install Android Studio: http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html#Installing

3. Follow steps outlined in the “Get Started with the Developer Preview” page

a) Prerequisites

b) Install the Android Wear System Image

c) Set up the Android Wear Emulator

d) Set up the Android Wear Preview App

e) Add the Support Library to Your Project

4. Try Android Wear code samples available in the Android Wear Developer Preview

a) WearableNotificationsSample

b) ElizaChat

c) RecipeAssistant

5. Read the Android Wear design principles

6. Watch the Android Wear DevBytes playlist (~15 minutes total)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1dQf0sANoDw&index=2&list=PLWz5rJ2EKKc-kIrPiq098QH9dOle-fLef

7. Join the +Android Wear Developers community: g.co/androidweardev

venue.name: Room K.4.401, Building K, Fourth Floor, ULB Campus Solbosh

name: Android Wearables Hands-on (together with GDG Brussels)

description:
This is a monthly workshop on Python, happening every third Tuesday of the month since March. Participation to previous events is not required.

Python is this thing called a programming language. It takes text that you’ve written (usually referred to as code), turns it into instructions for your computer, and runs those instructions. We’ll be learning how to write code to do cool and useful stuff. No longer will you be bound to use others’ programs to do things with your computer!

This workshop will offer complete beginners the opportunity to learn Python using the Introduction to Programming with Python [1] class from OpenTechSchool, and people with some some programming knowledge the opportunity to learn Python by building web applications through the easy Websites with Python Flask [2] class. [1] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-beginners/en/index.html
[2] http://opentechschool.github.io/python-flask/

venue.name: ULB Campus Solbosch Batiment K, third floor, room K.3.401

name: Learn Programming with Python (June)

description:
In this workshop you will learn to code in Scratch (scratch.mit.edu) the programming language used most widely in schools and kids programming clubs. Scratch was developed with love and kindness by MIT. It is fun, quick to learn, and has a visual interface that minimizes syntax errors. Scratch comes with a drawing tool and a wide assortment of pre-drawn art so that you can create a game or an animation within minutes of being introduced to this exciting visual language.

What we will cover: 
-The Scratch interface 
-Basic programming commands ("blocks") 
-Building your first game 
-How to motivate kids to learn to code


Note: This is NOT a session for kids.  If you are looking for free programming classes for kids in Brussels contact the workshop leaders or go to http://brussels.coderdojobelgium.be/.

Who this is for:  

• Parents who want to teach their kids to program. Teachers, coaches, and mentors from schools and programming clubs.

• Adults who want to learn the basics of programming using a really simple visual programming language.

Prerequisites: None 

Requirements: 

1) Bring your laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux, no problem) 

2) Optional: Download and set up Scratch on your machine. http://scratch.mit.edu/scratch2download/

Note: If you don’t have a laptop, warn us in advance so we can bring one for you.

The leaders of this workshop are Patrick Feeney and André Cortes, coaches from CoderDojo. CoderDojo is a volunteer-based programming club teaching kids programming for free. We are hoping the session will be useful to the general public and as well as our volunteers.
name: Learn how to Teach Scratch to Kids

description:
During this workshop, you will learn how to combine the easiness of IPython Notebook with the power of Pandas for data processing in Python.

The targeted audiences are scientists and other people doing data analysis. No prior knowledge of Python is required, but basic programming understanding is required (variables, functions, ...).

IPython Notebook is a web-based interactive computational environment where you can combine code execution, text, mathematics, plots and rich media into a single document.

pandas is a library providing high-performance, easy-to-use data structures and data analysis tools for the Python programming language.

-


The documentation we will be using during this workshop is available on GitHub and on my website : 


Web: http://hugoherter.com/F/IPython-Pandas/slides/

Download Zip: https://github.com/OpenTechSchool-Brussels/IPython-Pandas/archive/master.zip

Clone Git: https://github.com/OpenTechSchool-Brussels/IPython-Pandas

venue.name: ULB Building K, third floor, room K.3.201 (Campus Solbosch)

name: Learn Data analysis with IPython Notebook and Pandas

description:
Following on the success of the first session in early August we are proposing a second session to continue and build on what we learned. (For new attendees we will start from basics).

In this workshop you will learn to code in Scratch (scratch.mit.edu) the programming language used most widely in schools and kids programming clubs. Scratch was developed with love and kindness by MIT. It is fun, quick to learn, and has a visual interface that minimizes syntax errors. Scratch comes with a drawing tool and a wide assortment of pre-drawn art so that you can create a game or an animation within minutes of being introduced to this exciting visual language.

What we will cover:
-The Scratch interface
-Basic programming commands ("blocks")
-Building your first game
-How to motivate kids to learn to code Note: This is NOT a session for kids. If you are looking for free programming classes for kids in Brussels contact the workshop leaders or go to http://brussels.coderdojobelgium.be/.

Who this is for: • Parents who want to teach their kids to program. Teachers, coaches, and mentors from schools and programming clubs.

• Adults who want to learn the basics of programming using a really simple visual programming language.

Prerequisites: None Requirements: 1) Bring your laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux, no problem) 2) Optional: Scratch is a web-based tool and we have wifi but if you want to use the offline version for some reason go to: http://scratch.mit.edu/scratch2download/

Note: If you don’t have a laptop, warn us in advance so we can bring one for you.

The leaders of this workshop are Patrick Feeney and André Cortes, coaches from CoderDojo. CoderDojo is a volunteer-based programming club teaching kids programming for free. We are hoping the session will be useful to the general public and as well as our volunteers.
name: Learn how to Teach Scratch to Kids

description:
VVVV let you graphically create your project, quick and easy: no text or code needed. Everything is realtime: make your visuals interactive; modify your project and see the result on the fly (perfect for prototyping). VVVV is widely used for artistic installations, generative design and product showcases.


VVVV is a general purpose toolkit with a special focus on real-time motion graphics (interactive AfterEffect like rendering in real-time) and large media environments with physical interfaces (arduino, kinect…).

In VVVV, applications (patches) are visually programmed. You add nodes (boxes that do stuff) to your patch (network of nodes) and link nodes together to make them interact. Patches can be created, edited and tested while they are running.


VVVV is used for:

• Motion graphic & design [1], [2] (for instance for VJing [3]).

• Installations (artistic projects [4], product showcasing [5], [6], mapping [7], [8])

• Design (generative design [9], [10], data visualisation [11], [12], new interfaces [13], [14])


During this workshop, you will learn the basics of patching (programming in VVVV), how <a href="http://vimeo.com/27463592"></a>to navigate the VVVV ecosystem/toolkit in order to create interactive visuals & installations. By the end of the workshop, we hope to make you autonomous with VVVV so you can start your own projects.


Requirement:

1) Bring your laptop (Windows OS required, dual boot and Virtual Machine compatible).

2) Optional: Download and set up VVVV on your machine. (reference upcoming)

3) Optional : Bring a mouse! The middle button can be very useful.

Lead coach: Christophe

Coach: Roman, Aurelien

Materials: http://opentechschool-brussels.github.io/interactive-installations-with-VVVV/
name: Intro to VVVV, Easily Design Interactive Installations.

description:
If you want to help OTS, make it better or give it a new direction, this is the meeting for you!


It's been a hell of a year on OTS, from it's awakening, organisation, to the many workshop that were hosted (almost 30!). We won't rest on our laurels. Let's take advantage of OTS's birthday to meet and see how we can make it be better, add new activities, and make OTS fit better its growing community.

All questions and idea will be welcomed during the meeting, here is a growing list (don't hesitate to send me a mail to add some on the list):


• Organising OTS around three poles: Art/Design, Technique, Entrepreneurship. We would need at least one person per pole. 

• Launching the learner meetups, regular casual meetings for learners, where no OTS officials are required/needed.

• See who wants to help and what they can/want to help on. 

• Motivating other people to organise workshop / lead coach / coach.

• Searching for new places where to organise workshops.


• See what new kind of activities OTS can launch (hackathon, game jams, art hack days...)


• Many people joined but never showed up to workshops. What are the tresholds holding people back to join the workshop? (place, time, topic...)

• Connecting with other groups (university, art group, co-working spaces...) 

• Maybe OTS as a way to find a job? (either helping in founding a start up, or getting career opportunities...?)

• Reaching out to minorities in tech (or just newbies).


OTS will be better thanks to you, don't hesitate to voice your opinion and come to the meeting!
name: One year of OTS: Let's meet up and make the next one even better!

description:
All beginners welcome! Come learn how to beautifully visualize data. You will learn how to parse data, make a story out of it, and basics of its visualization. For that, we'll discover Processing, a programming language with an emphasis on visuals and interactions. With little tweaking, your end result will be an interactive visualization that run on computer, on Android and even straight on the web.

First you'll learn the basics of the Processing programming language, designed to facilitate the use of software within the visual arts, and to promote visual representations within technology. Processing is focused on making digital creation simple and fun. This makes it particularly fitted for makers, designers and visual artists from all level.

Once our first batch of skills acquired, we'll try our hands on some data visualization. From getting the data online, parsing it, getting its essence, to representing it in a fitted way so that the user can comprehend it better. We'll ask ourselves questions, and if data alone can't answer us properly, our visualization will. While we will have material to guide you, you are free to explore personal direction within this frame. If you have specific data or questions, don't hesitate to focus on those and see how what you learn can be applied to your personal project.

During this workshop, you will learn the basics of programming, how to use Processing and its development environment to create data representations that people can interact with. By the end of the workshop, we hope to make you autonomous with Processing so you can start your own projects.

Requirement:

1) Bring your laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux, no problem)
2) Optional: Download and set up Processing on your machine.

Lead Coach: Roman Miletitch

Coaches: No other yet, tell me if interested in coaching!

Materials: http://opentechschool-brussels.github.io/data-visualisation-with-processing/
name: Data visualisation with Processing

description:
The workshop is about creating a smartphone app using Android. In the manner of Open Tech School, you will learn at your own pace to start developing apps with Android. The course material is available on developer.android.com/training/index.html. However, we will use Android Studio instead of Eclipse.

Prerequisite is some programming knowledge, ideally in Java.

Please bring your own computer/laptop or leave a note below if you can't bring one.

Please bring an Android device or leave a note below if you can't bring one.

18:00 Preparing your laptop - Installation party for Android Studio - http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/studio.html

19:00 

A) Learn to program a Smartphone App on Android - http://developer.android.com/sdk/installing/create-project.html

B) Learn to program a Smartphone App with AppInventor - http://appinventor.mit.edu/explore/

Please install http://flagshipgame.eu/


22:00 Social

venue.name: Room K.4.401, Building K, Fourth Floor, ULB Campus Solbosh

name: Create your first Mobile App (with Android)

description:
In this workshop you will learn how to teach your kids basic HTML/CSS and how to create a website from scratch. By the end of the evening you will have a website that is live and up and running on the web. We will be working from first principles using open standards and free webhosting services (we will not use shortcuts such as google sites or wordpress.)

What we will cover:
- Basic HTML/CSS using CodeAcademy
- Creating an .html file using a text editor
- How to get free hosting and a free domain name
- How to upload files and launch a website
- How to motivate kids to learn web development from scratch

Note: This is NOT a session for kids but parents are free to bring their children with them.

Who this is for:
• Parents who want to teach their kids to program.
Teachers, coaches, and mentors from schools and programming clubs.

• Adults who want to learn the basics of web development from scratch (html/css)

Prerequisites: None
Requirements: Bring your laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux, no problem).

Note: If you don’t have a laptop, warn us in advance so we can bring one for you.

The leaders of this workshop are Patrick Feeney and André Madeira Cortes, coaches from CoderDojo. CoderDojo is a volunteer-based programming club teaching kids programming for free. We are hoping the session will be useful to the general public and as well as our volunteers.
name: Teach Kids to Create their Own Website in HTML/CSS

description:
http://coopcon.be/

A small ad-hoc conference on cooperative structures, hacker-community, co-living / -working -- with goal to create dynamic, spread the hackbase idea and concretise on some plans for the future.
name: Coopcon2014 conference

description:
This event will be a Living art Jam (a digital art hackathon) taking place from the 24th to the 26th of October with a vernissage the 26 at 20h. Living art and digital art have much in common, let's team up and show the world what can be done when you mix both. In real time, with intelligent behaviors and even some networks, you can create art piece with autonomous behaviors that can interact on a deep level with their environment and the public.

Our intention is to gather together beginners & professional artists from a broad spectrum of subjects (sound, code, dance, theater...) to form teams, create exploratory interactive work and share them together.

From Friday 24 octobre to Sunday 26 octobre.
Exhibition on the 26 Octobre at 20h.

Be sure to register too at: http://wikube.com/?q=node%2F16

For more information: wikube@wikube.com
name: Living ART JAM Session#1

description:
Usually web sites are build using HTML, CSS and Javascript. Nowadays, browsers support so-called web components, i.e. higher level HTML constructs that bundle more functionality. Examples are tabs, interactive buttons, signup forms.

The event is a full day event about web components and Google's Polymer, Firefox's Bricks and others. There will be talks in the morning and hands-on workshop in the afternoon. 

Requirements are basic understanding of HTML

REGISTRATION required at DevFest Day two http://www.meetup.com/gdg-brussels/events/212023862/
name: Building a Modern Web Site (with Web Components/Polymer) - part of GDG DevFest

description:
Come and discover Solr, a cross plateform & open source search platform. It allows you to perform searches on any document you might want (emails, website, calendars event, Word files, pdf...).

Solr is a complete and professional search solution:

- highlighting
- filtering
- fuzzy matching
- autocompletion ...

Running as a servlet and with its REST-like HTTP/XML and JSON APIs,  Solr is usable from most popular programming languages.

Requirements:

• Basic knowledge of coding (variable, functions, loop, conditional tests...).


Lead Coach: Vincent
Coaches: (send me a message if you want to participate)

Materials: Incoooming!
name: Information retrieval, Part 1 - Intro to Solr

description:
Come and discover Nutch, an open source and scalable search engine bearing the components of a full search engine:

- crawls the Internet
- extracts text from web pages (html, pdf, word docs ...)
- evaluates the relevance of web pages (with PageRank)
- indexes the text inside a search application - e.g. Solr - for later retrieval
- scales: can work on a cluster of machines for better performance


Requirements:

• Basic knowledge of coding (variable, functions, loop, conditional tests...).

Lead Coach: Vincent
Coaches: (send me a message if you want to participate)

Materials: Incoooming!
name: Information retrieval, Part 2 - Intro to Nutch

description:
Come learn how to program the brain of a robot and see how your behavior scale when many of them form a swarm and compete against others. Your experiments and these Artificial Intelligence multi-player games are set up in the ARGoS simulator, used for scientific research all over the world.

In this workshop, we will be using the Lua programming language to get hand on experience in Artificial Intelligence, robotics and swarm robotics. You will first learn how to code simple robotics behavior, from navigation and obstacle avoidance to collaboration among robots.

Once basic skills acquired, your aim will be to create specific Artificial Intelligences and confront them with the ones of fellow learners in various multi-player setup.

While those experiments are played as game, they will take place in ARGoS Simulator, providing you with rigorous scientific conditions. Interested in Artificial Intelligence or robotics? This will be the perfect test bed for you!

Thanks to Factory Forty Coworking for hosting this workshop!"


Requirements:

•  OK for Mac and Linux. If you cannot use anything but Windows, send me a message, we'll try to find a case by case solution.


• Basic knowledge of coding (variable, functions, loop, conditional tests...) and mathematics (trigonometry, vectors...) will help. No need to know Lua.

Lead Coach: Roman Miletitch
Coaches: (send me a message if you want to participate)


Materials: Incoooming!
name: Artificial Intelligence: code robots, create swarms, compete in games.
